awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I: Research on an energy harvesting system for the development of a self-sustainable, blue-tooth, low energy tracking and monitoring sensor for aircraft
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to develop a novel, self-sustaining, real-time asset tracking technology that addresses the aviation industry’s need for efficiency and safety. This technology will provide automated safety and emergency equipment compliance and security seal checks, significantly reducing the time required for audits, while increasing their accuracy and avoiding potential liability claims from undetected failure or tampering with safety equipment. Based on in-flight compliant Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) communication, equipment can be monitored continuously, during flight and on the ground, using a compact communication hub or mobile devices. Self-sustainability is achieved by harvesting energy from mechanical vibrations present in-flight and during taxiing, without requiring time-consuming battery change cycles and avoiding regulatory challenges for hazardous battery chemistries such as lithium-ion. The proposed research will also enable in-flight monitoring applications and automate new tasks such as ensuring compliance with in-flight seatbelt regulations. The proposed system will help passenger airlines stay profitable in a highly competitive market, realizing significant cost-savings through efficient operations, reduced turnaround times, and lower maintenance overheads. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project aims to evaluate a mechanical energy harvesting design regarding its technical feasibility and effectiveness as a power source for asset tracking devices onboard an aircraft. To this end, new technologies for mechanical energy harvesting will be tested: (1) a novel stacked piezoelectric device with tunable resonance frequencies and output enhanced by superposition among different piezo-elements vibrating in phase and (2) a mechanical vibration amplifier which extracts large-amplitude linear motions from vibrations to enhance the amplitude of mechanical movements. The two new technologies may enable the first mechanical vibration harvester which is compact enough to permit effective use in asset tracking in the aviation industry, resulting in an energy harvesting module miniaturized to comply with aviation applications and to efficiently harvest the extremely low frequencies (<10 Hz) dominating cabin vibrations. The energy harvesting circuit prototype will be evaluated under realistic deployment conditions within the scope of this project and integrated in BLE-sensor prototypes to further evaluate its performance.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Aircrafts have become a common form of transportation in the modern world. In an aircraft, miles of wiring are used to power many sensors that make an aircraft operational and safe. The wiring contributes to the weight resulting in higher fuel burn which is crucial to the efficiency of aircraft operation. Battery operated sensors seem to be an alternative however replacing batteries has become a major pain for the industry that deploys a big number of sensors and needs reliable uninterrupted data. Piezoelectric energy harvesting is a possible solution to overcome the issues, so AEROSENS has developed and demonstrated a vibration energy harvesting module optimized for a specific commercial aircraft. The module can power up an AEROSENS A20 real-time tamper-proof security tag which is the key component of AEROSENS cabin management solution based on Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) communication technology to monitor the real-time status of aircraft safety and emergency equipment or cabin compartments during flight. The proposed technology platform addresses the aviation industry’s need for efficiency and safety by reducing inspection time and alerting aircrew when passenger safety equipment is tampered with.

In this research, a piezoelectric cantilever was designed to harvest energy from low frequency aircraft vibrations and a mechanical amplification method was used to improve the energy conversion from the cantilever beam. The energy harvesting module was connected to an AEROSENS BLE tag which advertises the equipment status every two seconds with the average power consumption of about 0.033mW. A mobile or fixed monitoring device with AEROSENS App receives data from the A20 tag; and based on the data, updates the information concerning the aircraft equipment. This information indicates a current state of the equipment in the defined space of the aircraft.

AEROSENS flight tests data indicated the vibration resonance frequency is about the same for a specific commercial aircraft but varies from one aircraft model to another in a range of 35Hz to 120Hz. The research performed during Phase 1 has addressed this issue and we have developed a prototype properly functioning for Bombardier CRJ 700/CRJ 900/CRJ 1000 series aircrafts and proposed a high-level simple approach for the resonance frequency optimization in such a way that the same device can be adjusted to different commercial aircraft models.

The small form factor and solid AEROSENS BLE tag structure is ideally suited to life vest stowage units or seat belts and can offer airlines the opportunity to track open/closed status of life vest stowage units and seat belts during the flight. Once the tags are installed on equipment or cabin compartments, aircrew can pull up a layout of the aircraft cabin on their smart devices and monitor the status of the emergency equipment and immediately take any appropriate action. The AEROSENS solution can save airlines up to 98% of the equipment inspection time, while simultaneously increasing its accuracy, and avoiding potential liability claims arising from undetected failure or tampering with in-flight safety equipment.
